IRS Requires Taxes Even If You Don’t Live in the United States: What You Need to Know
02/18/2026 - 2:01 pm
by Rosalía Quintana

Do you have to file your tax return if you were deported or are outside the United States? Immigrants with deportation orders have tax obligations to the IRS. Details immediately.

Many people believe that being deported or having a deportation order in the United States eliminates their tax obligations, but this is not the case.

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) states that all taxpayers who earned income in the country must file a tax return, regardless of whether they physically reside in the U.S. or are outside the country for any reason, including deportation.

Jesús Flores, a tax preparer, tells Telemundo that the tax obligation remains in effect even if the person is no longer on U.S. territory.

According to tax experts, if someone worked and earned income in the United States, they must file their return with the IRS like any other taxpayer. Deportation does not eliminate this tax responsibility, and complying with it can prevent legal problems or future complications with immigration or financial procedures.

For those outside the country who need to declare, there are several options. One alternative is to contact a tax preparer authorized by the federal government, who can process the filing electronically with your authorization.

IRS in the United States on the hunt for taxes this season

This procedure allows the return to be filed from abroad through platforms like email or secure applications, even if the person is not physically present in the United States.

Regarding refunds, it is important to note that if the taxpayer receives one, they can authorize it to be directly deposited into a bank account. However, if the account is in a foreign country, it must be properly declared when submitting the tax return.

Another option to fulfill the tax obligation from outside the country is to appoint a representative through a power of attorney. The appropriate forms, such as Form 2848, allow a tax preparer or authorized representative to interact directly with the IRS on your behalf.

Correctly filing taxes, even if you are outside the country or facing a deportation order, is not only a legal obligation but can also help you avoid penalties, fines, or complications in future immigration or financial procedures in the United States.

item.title: [EN] Venden estaciones solares GWELL en Cuba: precios superan los 450 USD en tiendas de La Habana
item.description:
Translated:

GWELL Solar Stations Sold in Cuba: Prices Exceed 450 USD in Havana Stores
02/18/2026 - 1:11 pm
by
Roberto Jiménez
Three models of GWELL portable power plants arrive at foreign currency stores in Playa. Learn about the prices, capacities, and the controversy over their cost compared to Amazon.
The energy crisis in Cuba continues to drive a dollarized market that now bets on electrical autonomy at home. Recently, the arrival of a new line of portable solar stations from the Chinese brand GWELL was confirmed at the Panorama shopping centers (23 and 42) and 3ra y 70, both in the Playa municipality. These units, equipped with lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4) batteries, are marketed as a solution for blackouts, although their prices are prohibitive for most workers.
The offer from Tiendas Caribe includes three variants according to their output capacity. The basic model (GW600WP01), intended for fans and lights, costs 455.00 USD. The mid-range, which allows connecting televisions, sells for 550.00 USD, while the highest power model, capable of supporting a refrigerator or freezer, reaches 790.00 USD. All units allow charging via electrical grid or solar panels, although the latter are usually sold separately.
GWELL vs. Amazon: which option is cheaper for Cuba
The arrival of these power plants has sparked intense debate among Cubans on social media. The point of friction is not just the technology, but the price comparison with the international market and private importers. Users like L. Campos denounced the cost difference compared to external platforms: "They sell it more expensive than Amazon; an Ecoflow of similar capacity costs 399 USD, and adding shipping is still cheaper."
On the other hand, supporters of the state offer like C. Manuel argue that import costs and local warranty justify the price. "When you add the import cost [for what is brought from abroad], it is almost double. At least here you have a warranty if the equipment is defective," he commented. However, the reality is that the informal market continues to compete closely with these prices, offering globally recognized brands.
Real solution or "medicine for the sick"?
For many Cubans, the sale of these units is seen cynically due to the instability of the National Electric System. User M. Adames summed up the feeling of several customers with a scathing phrase: "I make you sick and then sell you the medicine." The criticism points out that, while the state fails to stabilize power supply, it markets in hard currency the tools to alleviate the effects of such instability.
The commercialization of these GWELL stations in the state retail network has aroused suspicion among consumers, who point out the contradiction that the state dollarizes alternatives in the face of an energy crisis it cannot solve. For the average Cuban, the offer is perceived as a fundraising strategy amid the precariousness of the National Electric System.

item.title: [EN] Licencia de conducción cubana en Canadá: ¿Qué reglas aplican para turistas y residentes en 2026?
item.description:
Translated:

Cuban Driver’s License in Canada: What Rules Apply for Tourists and Residents in 2026?
02/18/2026 - 12:06 pm
by
Roberto Jiménez
Driving in Canada with a Cuban license is possible, but there are limits. The Consulate in Ottawa clarifies the 6-month deadlines for visits and the key procedure for those arriving to reside in 2026.
The Consulate in Ottawa confirms: The Cuban license is valid, but it has an expiration date
Many Cubans arriving in Canada ask the same question: Can I use my island driver's license or do I have to get a new one from scratch? According to the latest information from the Cuban Consulate in Ottawa, Cubans entering as tourists or on a temporary stay can drive with their valid license for a maximum of 6 months.
However, the
official note
is not just to inform that the license is valid. The diplomatic office is promoting the certification of the Cuban license. This procedure, managed directly at the consulate, aims for Canadian provincial authorities to recognize the years you have been driving in Cuba. If you manage to validate that experience, you could save time in Canada’s graduated licensing system and advance more quickly to exams for higher categories, such as the G Full in Ontario.
For those planning to process this in 2026, the requirements remain: you must present your updated Cuban passport and a valid Cuban driver’s license. The process is coordinated by email or WhatsApp to expedite the delivery of documents.
Rules by province: Quebec is not the same as Ontario
A common mistake among newcomers is to think traffic laws are national. In Québec (SAAQ), if you come on a visit, you can use your Cuban license for 6 consecutive months. Now, if you decide to stay and change your status to resident, that deadline remains, but after that time you are required to get the province’s license.
In Ontario, the situation is stricter for those who move there: you only have 60 days to drive with your foreign license before having to apply for the provincial one. Since Cuba does not have a direct exchange agreement with Canada, you will have to take the exams (theory and practical). Here is where consular certification comes to the rescue, as it proves you are not a beginner and often allows you to go straight to the final road test.
One point the consulate doesn’t mention but any Cuban in Toronto or Montreal knows is the insurance issue. Even if your Cuban license is legal for six months, many insurers either don’t provide coverage or charge a fortune if you don’t have a Canadian local license.

MINCIN reports on donations and basic food baskets in Havana and other provinces
02/18/2026 - 11:09 am
by
Marisela Jiménez
The distribution of rationed food and donations has begun in several provinces around the country. In some areas, the delivery of products from Mexico has started. In others, pending distributions for February are progressing.
Local authorities have specified which groups benefit and what items are delivered in each case. These are the details confirmed so far.
Artemisa: donation in Güira de Melena
In Güira de Melena, Artemisa province, products from the donation sent by Mexico were received.
In the municipality, 30 children with low weight and height, 88 pregnant women, 5541 children from 0 to 13 years old, and 361 vulnerable households benefit.
Children with low weight receive 1 package of rice and 2 cans of sardines.
Pregnant women receive 3 packages of rice and 2 packages of cookies.
Children from 0 to 13 years receive 1 package of cookies.
Vulnerable households receive 1 package of cookies per household.
Authorities advised consulting official channels to know the schedule by grocery store.
Havana: distribution across the 15 municipalities
In the capital, the distribution of the Mexican donation intended for children with low weight and height has begun.
The package includes 1 package of rice, 1 package of beans, 1 unit of oil, 2 units of sardines, 3 units of amaranth, 2 packages of María cookies, and 1 unit of peach.

Distribution is organized by municipality and popular council, according to availability in commercial units.
Holguín: progress in Urbano Noris
In Urbano Noris, 2 pounds of donation rice per consumer for February were distributed.
Also, 10 days of milk were given to children from 0 to 11 months and 29 days in the three popular councils in the urban area.
In La Cuchilla and El Níspero, 1 pound of sugar and 10 ounces of peas for the current month were added. Additionally, cigarettes were distributed for those over 18 years old and 2 cigars per household from December.
This Tuesday, 10 more days of milk were added for children from 0 to 11 months, completing 20 days in February.
Granma: distribution of donation from WFP
In Granma province, the distribution of food donated by the World Food Programme continues.
The distribution benefits children under 5 years old, pregnant women, and people over 65 years old.
Deliveries are made in grocery stores linked to the corresponding UEBs in popular councils such as Rosa la Bayamesa, Aeropuerto Viejo, and Jesús Menéndez.
Beneficiaries must present the updated ration booklet and identity card when collecting the products.

item.title: [EN] Cuba prevé apagones de hasta 1763 MW este 18 de febrero pese al aporte solar
item.description:
Translated:

Cuba anticipates blackouts of up to 1763 MW this February 18 despite solar contribution
02/18/2026 - 10:29 am
by
Alberto Viera
Electricity generation fell short of demand again in Cuba this February 18. The deficit continued throughout the previous day and into the early morning.
Official figures confirm another day marked by prolonged blackouts in several provinces. The nighttime peak was once again the most critical time.
Sustained deficit over 24 hours
The electricity service was affected by capacity shortfall throughout the previous day. The maximum impact reached 1793 MW at 7:10 pm.
This figure reflects the gap between what the system can generate and what the country needs to consume. The situation did not improve during this morning's early hours.
At 6:00 am, the availability of the National Electric System was 1280 MW. Demand at that time was 2170 MW. This left 915 MW uncovered.
For midday, an impact of 900 MW is estimated.
Contribution from solar parks
The 51 photovoltaic solar parks generated 3968 MWh during the day. The maximum power delivered was 760 MW during peak radiation hours.
Although the solar contribution is significant, it does not offset the outage of several thermal units. Renewable generation also depends on weather conditions.
ALSO READ:
Fuel sales in Cuba: fraud warning regarding a fake Ticket app amid the energy crisis
Breakdowns and maintenance at thermoelectric plants
The system is experiencing breakdowns in Unit 2 of the Santa Cruz Thermal Power Plant, Unit 2 of the Felton Thermal Power Plant, and Units 5 and 6 of the Antonio Maceo Thermal Power Plant.
Maintenance continues on Unit 6 of the Mariel Thermal Power Plant, Unit 5 of the Nuevitas Thermal Power Plant, and Unit 4 of the Carlos Manuel de Céspedes Thermal Power Plant in Cienfuegos.
Additionally, limitations in thermal generation are keeping 466 MW out of service.
Forecast for peak hours
For peak hours, the Mariel fuel site is expected to come online with 112 MW. The addition of 5 engines at the Patana de Regla with 45 MW is also anticipated.
At the Moa fuel site, 6 engines are expected to synchronize, adding 85 MW.
With these additions, the projected availability for the peak would be 1437 MW. The estimated maximum demand is 3170 MW.
This would leave a deficit of 1733 MW. If forecasted conditions hold, the impact could reach 1763 MW during that period.
ALSO READ:

The gap between supply and demand continues to shape the behavior of the electrical system in February. Forecasts point to another night of extended outages.

item.title: [EN] Sheinbaum mantiene en cero el envío de petróleo a Cuba: “Por lo pronto no”
item.description:
Translated:

Sheinbaum keeps oil shipments to Cuba at zero: "For now, no"
02/18/2026 - 10:01 am
by
Rosalía Quintana
The president of Mexico once again confirmed this Tuesday that she will maintain humanitarian aid to Cuba, but without sending oil due to tariffs imposed by the United States against countries that sell crude oil to the island’s government.
The president of Mexico, Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo, stated this Tuesday that her government will not send oil to Cuba "for now," although she confirmed that humanitarian aid destined for the island will continue.
The statement was made during her usual morning press conference, where she answered questions about the bilateral relationship and energy cooperation.
Sheinbaum specified that Mexico will continue sending food and other support requested by the Cuban government, but made it clear that the supply of fuels is not part of the immediate actions. "No, for now we are not going to send fuels," she said when directly questioned on the matter.
The president’s words come in a complex context for Cuba, which is going through a severe energy crisis characterized by prolonged blackouts and fuel shortages. The lack of oil has impacted electricity generation and transportation on the island, increasing economic difficulties.
ALSO READ:
Canada warns about travel to Cuba and its risks
Despite the decision regarding crude oil, Sheinbaum reiterated that her administration maintains its commitment to humanitarian support for the Cuban people. She emphasized that Mexico will continue collaborating with food and other requests considered priorities.
The president also expressed her disagreement with the imposition of tariffs on countries that trade oil with Cuba, defending the right of each nation to make sovereign decisions in foreign policy. In that regard, she recalled that the Mexican Constitution supports the principle of self-determination of peoples.
Moreover, Sheinbaum reiterated Mexico’s willingness to act as a diplomatic bridge between Cuba and the United States.
She explained that her government has communicated to both the U.S. Department of State and its diplomatic representation in Mexican territory the willingness to facilitate bilateral dialogue, always respecting sovereignty.
Mexico’s stance marks a balance between humanitarian solidarity and prudence in energy matters, at a time when Cuba’s electric crisis generates regional concern.

item.title: [EN] Aerovaradero informa sobre el estado actual de los envíos a Cuba
item.description:
Translated:

Aerovaradero reports on the current status of shipments to Cuba
02/18/2026 - 9:11 am
by
Roberto Jiménez
Aerovaradero reports on the status of shipments to Cuba amid fuel shortages. The company assures that cargo is not blocked and explains delays in eastern provinces.
Aerovaradero clarifies the status of parcels in Cuba
The company Aerovaradero S.A. reported that shipments to Cuba continue to operate and that cargo is not blocked, despite the temporary fuel shortage affecting transportation in the country.
The statement, published on its official channels, responds to concerns from customers inside and outside the Island about possible stoppages in parcel delivery. According to the entity, packages remain in motion and the logistics chain remains active with both in-house and subcontracted staff.
Aerovaradero belongs to the Cuban Aviation Corporation and specializes in national and international air cargo, as well as the operation of cargo terminals and related services. The company has offices in Havana, Varadero, Gerona, Santa Clara, Cienfuegos, Camagüey, Santiago de Cuba, and Holguín.
According to the
official information,
Havana and nearby areas have greater distribution flow. In contrast, eastern provinces and more distant municipalities may experience delays of several days due to distance and limitations in ground transportation associated with fuel.
On social media, several users expressed concern about specific delays. H. Quiñones asked about the situation of shipments to Pinar del Río. L. Álvarez stated that they have had cargo in Santiago de Cuba since October without receiving it and noted a lack of telephone response. A. Orama also questioned the dispatch order of some packages. The company responded that it reviews each case via private message and advised using the tracking system available on its official website.
Official statement from Aerovaradero S.A.
TO OUR BIG FAMILY: IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT YOUR SHIPMENTS
At #AerovaraderoSA, we know that every package you send contains a piece of heart, a hug, or a necessity for your loved ones in #Cuba. That is why we want to be completely transparent with you given the current situation.
Due to the temporary fuel shortage the country is facing, we understand that questions may arise. We want to convey calm and clarity with the following points:
CARGO IS NOT BLOCKED. Your packages are safe and in motion.
DELIVERIES CONTINUE. Our own team and subcontractors are working tirelessly to ensure the logistics chain remains unbroken.
Here is the current situation:
· Havana and nearby areas: Continue to be the points of greatest flow.
· Eastern provinces and distant municipalities: Due to distance and current logistical complexity, delivery times may be longer by a few days than usual. We ask for your patience; our transporters are giving their best to reach every corner.
WE ARE LOOKING FOR NEW ALTERNATIVES to optimize deliveries and minimize any impact. As soon as we have updates or new routes available, we will inform you immediately via this same channel. We will keep our customers informed at all times.
REMEMBER: You can track your cargo at any time through our website:
www.aerovaradero.com.cu
On our part, we will continue doing everything possible to ensure that shipments keep reaching their destinations. We are committed to staying close to families and the Cuban people in this very complex moment because we know that distance shrinks when memories and help arrive home.
Thank you for your continued trust.
Tracking shipments to Cuba and logistical context
Aerovaradero reiterated that it has not suspended operations. The company recommends customers check the status of shipments to Cuba through the tracking system enabled on its website. This service allows verification of whether cargo is in classification, in transit, or ready for delivery.
The fuel shortage mainly impacts ground transportation, a key stage to complete distribution to municipalities far from the main logistics centers. For this reason, delivery times may vary by province.
The status of shipments to Cuba remains one of the most queried topics by the diaspora and families who depend on international parcels. Medicines, food, and essential articles are usual components of these shipments.

item.description:
Translated:

Food and hygiene delivery sent by Mexico: this is how it will be distributed in these provinces
02/18/2026 - 8:04 am
by
Rosalía Quintana
As communicated, Mexico sent aid to Cuba, consisting of food and hygiene products. Distribution began in Havana and other western provinces on February 17.
The Ministry of Internal Trade of Cuba (MINCIN)
reported
yesterday, February 17, the start of the distribution of the solidarity aid sent by the government of Mexico, which has already begun to be delivered in Havana and will progressively extend to the provinces of Artemisa and Mayabeque.
According to the official information provided to the Cuban people, the donation sent by the brotherly Mexican government arrived in Havana in recent days. The aid is made up of food and hygiene products, in a context marked by supply difficulties and high demand for basic items on the island.
The distribution will benefit residents in Artemisa, Havana, Mayabeque, and the special municipality Isla de la Juventud. Authorities specified that
priority will be given to children from 0 to 13 years old,
people over 65 years old, pregnant women, and children with low weight and height. Families in vulnerable situations in Havana and Mayabeque will also be attended to.

Informal and official currency market in Cuba today: updated rates
According to MINCIN, the logistical operation is being carried out as quickly as possible in the processes of receiving, organizing, and distributing products. Shipments will gradually arrive in each territory, in coordination with trade structures and local authorities.
The distribution is part of the bilateral cooperation mechanisms between Cuba and Mexico, amid a complex economic scenario for the island. Although specific volumes by province were not detailed, authorities emphasized that the objective is to ensure that the most vulnerable sectors of the population receive the resources first.
The Cuban government reiterated its gratitude to the people and government of Mexico for the solidarity gesture, highlighting that this type of donation helps to alleviate, although temporarily, the supply situation in certain prioritized groups.
It is expected that in the coming days the arrival and internal transfer of products to the distribution points established in each territory will continue.

item.title: [EN] Gaceta Oficial: Aduana de Cuba amplía exención de impuestos en nuevas importaciones
item.description:
Translated:

Official Gazette: Cuban Customs Extends Tax Exemption on New Imports
02/18/2026 - 7:02 am
by
Marisela Jiménez

The Official Gazette of the Republic of Cuba published a new decision related to the payment of border tariffs, adding to the previous decision to keep the importation of food, medicines, and hygiene products tax-free.

The measure expands the tax exemption and establishes benefits for certain import operations of various items.

The provision appears in Resolution 21/2026 of the Ministry of Finance and Prices. The text confirms that the Customs Tax exemption is extended in a context marked by economic tensions and low availability of supplies.

The regulation makes clear that the exemption remains without a fixed expiration date. It will be in effect as long as economic conditions require it. It applies to operations carried out since January 1, 2026.

What does the expansion announced in the Gazette imply?

The Customs Tax is collected through border tariffs. Its temporary elimination reduces the cost of goods entering the country. In this case, the benefit is not general for travelers or individual consumers.

The extension maintains what was stipulated in a previous resolution issued in November 2024. That regulation exempted economic agents who imported goods intended for production processes or to ensure those productions from paying tariffs.

ALSO READ:
Flights to Cuba: Iberia offers refunds and flight changes to passengers who bought tickets to Cuba

Now, that treatment is extended over time. No new specific deadline is set. The Ministry reserves the possibility of maintaining it as long as the situation justifies it.

Who really benefits from the measure?

The scope is directed at economic agents who import to produce goods or sustain services. This includes micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs), cooperatives, and other recognized management forms.

It is not an open exemption for the entire population. Nor does it modify the current rules for travelers or personal shipments. In previous months, benefits related to duty-free importation of food, medicines, and hygiene products ceased to be extended.

In this case, the goal is to support internal productive activity. Reducing the cost of inputs can alleviate financial pressures on companies that depend on imported raw materials.

Impact on prices and production

Eliminating the tariff implies a lower initial cost in the import operation. However, the final effect on consumer prices will depend on other factors. Exchange rates, transport, and commercial margins influence.

The Government justifies the decision under current economic conditions. The regulation invokes powers granted by the Tax System Law and the Constitution to grant exemptions when economic and social circumstances advise it.

ALSO READ:
CIMEX enables gasoline purchase in USD by Ticket: How many liters per shift?

In a scenario of supply shortages and low national production, the measure seeks to facilitate the entry of goods intended to generate goods and services in the country.

The publication in the Official Gazette confirms that the exemption remains active. Its permanence will depend on economic developments in the coming months.

Informal and official currency exchange market in Cuba today: updated rates
02/18/2026 - 6:24 am
by
Rosalía Quintana
Euro, Zelle, MLC, and dollar: this is how currency exchange in Cuba looks this morning, February 18, both in the informal market and at the official Central Bank. The gap between official and informal rates is growing.
The price of currencies today in Cuba shows marked differences between reference rates and the informal market, which continues to be the main thermometer for the population.
While the US dollar is set at 458.00 CUP according to reference values, in the informal market it already reaches 500.00 CUP, according to real-time monitoring published by the independent outlet El Toque.
The euro also shows a significant gap. Although it is reported at 542.41 CUP in official tables, in the informal market it is quoted at 560.00 CUP this February 18 at 3:23 AM in Cuba. This difference reflects the strong demand for foreign currency on the island.
The British pound continues to be the highest value currency, at 620.45 CUP in general listings, although the parallel market tends to adjust its figures in line with the euro. The Canadian dollar stands at 335.60 CUP in reference rates, while in the informal market it appears at 335.00 CUP, with a reported increase of +5 CUP.
ALSO READ:

The Mexican peso rises in the informal market up to 29.19 CUP (+0.25), above the 26.72 CUP reflected in other tables. The Chinese yuan remains at 66.29 CUP in reference values, while the Russian ruble marks 6.00 CUP and the Japanese yen 0.33 CUP.
One of the most followed indicators is the MLC, which in the informal market is quoted at 410.00 CUP, with a decrease of -10.27 CUP. Also notable are transactions through Zelle, valued at 493.62 CUP (-0.16), and the so-called CLA, which reaches 488.89 CUP (+1.41).
The behavior of the informal currency market in Cuba responds directly to the actual supply and demand of cash and transfers. In a context of inflation and scarcity, the price of the dollar today in Cuba and the value of the euro set the benchmark for prices of food, appliances, and services.
The gap between official rates and the informal market confirms that the latter continues to be the main economic reference for those buying or selling foreign currency on the island. Therefore, daily monitoring of currencies has become a regular practice for families, entrepreneurs, and merchants.

item.title: [EN] Accidente masivo en Camagüey: vuelca medibus con embarazadas y menores
item.description:
Translated:

Massive accident in Camagüey: medibus with pregnant women and minors overturns
02/18/2026 - 5:55 am
by
Rosalía Quintana
Seven pregnant women and four children among those affected in a massive accident on the Central Highway in Camagüey. This is what is known.
A massive traffic accident occurred on the night of Tuesday, February 17 near the town of Cascorro, in the province of Camagüey, when a bus used as a Medibus for transporting patients lost control and overturned on the Central Highway.
According to information released by official journalist Pedro Cruz Moiset and reports from Radio Guáimaro, the accident involved at least 56 people. The driver reportedly lost control while performing a maneuver on the road, causing the overturn.
Among the passengers were seven pregnant women, who were taken to the city of Camagüey to receive specialized medical care. Additionally, four children were sent to the Guáimaro hospital for evaluation and follow-up.
Radio Guáimaro updated at dawn that there were 47 minor injuries, 7 pregnant women not in life-threatening condition but with trauma from the impacts, 4 children: one being evaluated by the pediatrician and three without injuries, and 5 seriously ill patients transferred to Camagüey.
ALSO READ:
Official MINCIN information on the basic basket in Havana
Authorities indicated that all passengers are being evaluated by medical personnel to rule out subsequent complications.
The incident occurred on a stretch of the Central Highway near Cascorro, an area with frequent interprovincial vehicle and medical transport traffic. The Medibus involved in the accident was performing patient transfers with medical appointments, adding sensitivity to the event.
This traffic accident in Camagüey again highlights road safety in Cuba, especially in vehicles intended for medical services. Investigations continue to precisely determine the causes of the incident and establish responsibilities.
Meanwhile, relatives of the passengers and residents of the area have been closely following the condition of those affected. Health authorities maintain surveillance over the health status of pregnant women and minors involved in the accident.
It is expected that official information on this massive accident in Camagüey will be expanded in the coming hours, which fortunately has not left any fatalities up to this moment.

item.title: [EN] Anuncian cambios en el Consulado español en La Habana para aliviar la saturación
item.description:
Translated:

Announce changes at the Spanish Consulate in Havana to ease saturation
02/17/2026 - 6:57 pm
by
Rosalía Quintana
Consular services in Havana will undergo a period of significant changes affecting both Spanish citizens and descendants requiring essential services, amid strong demand for procedures such as nationality acquisition, document legalization, and visas.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs, European Union and Cooperation of Spain has begun an appointment process that includes two consuls and one deputy consul for Havana, as part of a broader renewal of the Spanish diplomatic network abroad published in the Official State Bulletin.
These changes respond to pressure accumulated from years of saturation at the Spanish consulate in Havana, which has seen an increasing volume of requests related to the Democratic Memory Law, popularly known as the “Grandchildren Law,” allowing thousands of descendants of Spaniards to begin nationality procedures.
Criticism and complaints about delays, difficulties obtaining appointments, and long waiting times have been frequent, motivating measures such as appointing new diplomatic personnel and expanding capacities.
In addition to the positions to be filled in Havana, the Spanish government has also considered strengthening other districts with high demand, demonstrating the intention to modernize and streamline consular services.
ALSO READ:
Quotas bread in Cuba: the State resorts to firewood for cooking and animal traction for transport
A recent priority has been improving the appointment and scheduling system for procedures such as document legalization, with an announced increase in the availability of weekly appointments and the transition to more efficient digital platforms.
The impact of these measures goes beyond a simple diplomatic reorganization: for many Cubans and Spaniards residing on the island, a consulate with greater capacity means reduced waiting times that, in some cases, exceeded one year.
This is especially critical for those looking to regularize their legal status in Spain or complete citizenship procedures dependent on strict deadlines.
The creation of new consular offices in other Cuban cities, such as Camagüey, has also been proposed, aiming to decentralize services and reduce saturation in Havana. The opening of a new Consulate General in that city seeks to bring services closer to residents of the central and eastern parts of the island and ease the load on the capital. But so far, there have been no advances in this regard.
Together, these initiatives reflect a sustained effort by Spain to adapt its consular presence in Cuba to a reality where demand far exceeds traditional service capacity, driven by recent laws, migratory flows, and the need for more agile responses to the bureaucratic challenges faced by applicants.

item.description:
Translated:

Costa Rica Advises Its Citizens to Leave Cuba: “Leave the Island While Flights Are Available”
02/17/2026 - 5:48 pm
by
Roberto Jiménez
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Worship of Costa Rica has asked its nationals to leave Cuba due to shortages of fuel, electricity, and basic goods, and has suspended non-essential travel.
The Government of Costa Rica urged its citizens in Cuba to leave the country while commercial flights are still available. The recommendation responds to the worsening shortage of fuel, electricity, and basic goods, including food, water, and medicine.
The notice was
issued
by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Worship on February 16, 2026, through an official statement released on its institutional channels. The text notes that the current situation on the island affects basic living conditions and may limit mobility and access to essential services.
“All Costa Rican nationals on the island are urged to leave while commercial flights remain available,”
the official statement indicates.
The note also recommends suspending all non-essential travel to Cuba until further notice. The institution warns that the possibilities of evacuating Costa Rican citizens, whether residents or tourists, are very limited in case of an emergency. “Currently, there are no economic or material resources available to carry out such operations,” the statement specifies.
Consulate in Havana Offers Direct Assistance
The Ministry informed that those needing consular support can contact the Costa Rican Consulate General in Havana. The office has enabled the email concr-[email protected] and phone numbers (0053) 7204-6937 and (0053) 7204-6938 to assist its nationals.
The official communication does not provide figures on the number of Costa Ricans residing in or visiting Cuba. It also does not specify additional measures beyond the preventive exit recommendation and suspension of non-essential travel.
In recent months, the island has faced prolonged blackouts, difficulties in fuel distribution, and shortages of food and medicine. Cuban authorities have acknowledged impacts on electricity generation and the importation of basic supplies due to a lack of foreign currency.
So far, the Cuban Government has not publicly responded to the Costa Rican statement.

item.title: [EN] Seguro de auto en EE.UU: lo que no te dicen antes de pagar una reparación
item.description:
Translated:

Car Insurance in the U.S.: What They Don’t Tell You Before Paying for a Repair
02/17/2026 - 4:54 pm
by
Rosalía Quintana
A repair on a car that seemed to be covered by the warranty ended up costing a driver from South Florida, U.S., more than $700. The case came to light after the affected person sought help from Telemundo 51, eventually achieving a solution after several months of uncertainty.
Débora Prado, a regular viewer of
Telemundo 51
and the sister network NBC6, said she bought a new 2024 Toyota Corolla. After driving 32,000 miles, the “Check Engine” light turned on. When she initially went to a mechanic, she was told the vehicle was still under warranty and that she should bring it directly to the official dealership.
At the Toyota dealer in Doral, Prado recounted, she was informed that she had to contact the corporation to confirm if the repair was covered.
According to her account, she was assured by phone that the repair qualified but that she had to pay first and then request a reimbursement. Trusting that information, she paid $703 for the repair.
The problem was not the mechanical repair, but the subsequent process. Prado explained that she was asked to download an app to submit the documentation and process the reimbursement. She was told the check would arrive within three months, but five months passed without a response.
ALSO READ:
Mexican Government Sends Over 800 Tons of Humanitarian Aid to Cuba Including Rice, Beans, Milk, Meat, Oil, and Basic Products
After contacting Telemundo 51 Responde, the station’s team reached out to the dealership. The general manager explained that the repaired part — a cooling system valve — was not covered by either the basic warranty or the powertrain warranty, which primarily covers the engine, transmission, and drivetrain.
They also checked if the vehicle qualified for any special service programs, but the VIN number did not qualify.
Subsequently, upon contacting Toyota’s corporation, the driver received an alternative: a $750 credit for a future repair. Although she did not get a direct reimbursement, she considered the solution satisfactory.
This case offers several lessons for owners of new vehicles. Before authorizing a repair, it is crucial to request written confirmation of warranty coverage. It is also advisable to review the warranty contract, as not all parts are included, and there are differences between the basic warranty, powertrain warranty, and special programs.

item.title: [EN] Aeropuerto cubano actualiza los vuelos que seguirán operando en su terminal
item.description:
Translated:

Cuban airport updates flights that will continue operating at its terminal
02/17/2026 - 3:51 pm
by
Rosalía Quintana
Urgent update due to the fuel crisis at Cuban airports: confirmed flights to and from Santiago de Cuba on these February dates.
Despite the fuel crisis affecting air operations in Cuba, several airlines maintain their scheduled flights during February at the Antonio Maceo Grajales International Airport, located in Santiago de Cuba.
Airport authorities have confirmed that, so far, these frequencies remain active, although passengers are advised to stay alert for possible adjustments.
American Airlines maintains operations with five weekly frequencies from Miami to Antonio Maceo Grajales International Airport. Flights are scheduled for Sundays, Mondays, Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays, guaranteeing stable connectivity between South Florida and eastern Cuba.
Meanwhile, Havanatur charters continue operating on Sundays and Thursdays also from Miami, while Air Century maintains its frequencies on Mondays and Fridays from the Dominican Republic.
ALSO READ:

Fly Allways will continue connecting on Mondays from Porlamar and on Tuesdays from Camagüey. Meanwhile, Cubana de Aviación retains its flights on Tuesdays from Madrid and Thursdays from Havana.
Additionally, Sky High maintains operations on Wednesdays from the Dominican Republic, along with specific flights on Thursday, February 19 from Havana and Saturday, February 21 from Dominican territory. Finally, interCaribbean Airways continues flying on Wednesdays from Kingston to Santiago de Cuba.
Authorities insist that, due to the energy situation impacting fuel supply in the country, last-minute changes could occur. Passengers are advised to check directly with each airline before heading to the airport.
Amid uncertainty, these operations represent a partial guarantee of international and national connectivity for travelers, emigrants, and tourists needing to travel to and from Santiago de Cuba during February.
